title: 106_hr5039
content: The Medicare Choice Preservation Act of 2000 is the short title of this Act. It includes improvements in payments. The Medicare Choice Preservation Act of 2000 includes improvements in payments, such as an increase in national per capita Medicare+Choice growth percentage, increasing minimum payment amount, allowing movement to 50:50 percent blend, and more. The Medicare Choice Preservation Act of 2000 includes delays in deadlines for offering and withdrawing Medicare+Choice plans, miscellaneous regulatory changes, effectiveness of elections, uniform premium and benefits, and compatibility with employer group health plans. Additionally, there is an increase in the national per capita Medicare+Choice growth percentage for 2001 and 2002. SEC. 102 of the Medicare Choice Preservation Act of 2000 increases the minimum payment amount to $475 for 2001 for all states and the District of Columbia. This amendment applies to years starting from 2001. SEC. 103 allows for a 50:50 percent blend movement in 2002. SEC. 103 allows Medicare+Choice organizations to choose a 50:50 blend for 2002. SEC. 104 increases the minimum percentage increase for 2001. SEC. 105 provides an increased update for payment areas with only one or no Medicare+Choice contracts. SEC. 103 allows Medicare+Choice organizations to choose a 50:50 blend for 2002. SEC. 104 increases the minimum percentage increase for 2001. SEC. 105 provides an increased update for payment areas with only one or no Medicare+Choice contracts. Section 1853(c)(1)(C)(ii) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a provision for Medicare+Choice payment areas with only one contract, setting the capitation rate at 104.5 percent for specific years. The amendments made by subsection (a) do not affect the payment of a first-time bonus under section 1853(i) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 106 eliminates budget neutrality adjustment for 2001 and 2002 in the Social Security Act. SEC. 107 revises the calculation of area-specific rate. SEC. 107 revises the calculation of area-specific rate without considering certain paragraphs. Effective from January 1, 2001, the amendments apply to years after 2000. SEC. 108 introduces a 10-year phase-in of risk adjustment based on data from all settings. SEC. 108 introduces a 10-year phase-in of risk adjustment based on data from all settings, starting in 2004 and phased in over a 10-year period. The deadline for Medicare+Choice organizations to withdraw offering a plan for 2001 is delayed to November 15, 2000. Organizations can rescind withdrawal before this date. The deadline for Medicare+Choice organizations to withdraw plan offerings for 2001 is extended to November 15, 2000, with the option to rescind withdrawal before this date. Section 1853(a)(3)(B) of the Social Security Act is amended to prohibit the submission of encounter data for risk adjustment until complete requirements are issued by the Secretary. The Secretary must issue data submission requirements for Medicare+Choice organizations to support risk adjustment methodology, evaluated by an independent actuary. Post-stabilization guidelines are also amended to delay encounter data submission until complete requirements are issued. Post-stabilization care guidelines for Medicare+Choice organizations require notification within 2 hours of stabilization for approval before providing care related to the emergency condition. The emergency services provider must respond to a request within 3 hours of being notified and maintain written documentation of the notice and response. SEC. 203 amends the Social Security Act regarding elections. The effective date is January 1, 2001. SEC. 204 modifies premium and benefits across counties. Effective date is January 1, 2001. SEC. 205 addresses Medicare+Choice program compatibility with employer or union group health plans. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows for Medicare+Choice plans to be offered through contracts with employers, labor organizations, or trustees of a fund, with waivers or modifications to requirements that hinder plan design or enrollment. Effective January 1, 2001.
